sentence: Wall Street's benchmark averages are mixed Tuesday with the Dow Jones Industrial Average struggling to stay positive, but the Nasdaq and S&P 500 weighed down by losses in the consumer and energy sectors.
Early gains tied to upbeat economic data unraveled at the open as the S&P 500 failed to penetrate the 200-hour moving average, and profit-taking emerged after three days of solid gains.
Stocks were marginally higher at the open as risk aversion continued to dissipate after North Korea downplayed an impending military strike on Guam.
Accordingly, demand for safe-havens continued to evaporate with gold lower for a second straight day, and the 10-year yield up another 3 basis points from Monday's close.
The latest round of economic data was mostly bullish as all measures beat or met Wall Street expectations beginning with a 0.6% gain in retail sales, twice what analysts predicted.
Excluding autos and gas, sales were up 0.5% versus 0.4% estimates.

Manufacturing in the New York Fed region accelerated dramatically, driving the Empire State manufacturing index to 25.2 from 9.8 in July, a measurable beat from expectations to remain unchanged at 9.8.

The housing market index rose to its highest level in three months to 68 from 64, beating estimates to increase by a point, while business inventories were up 0.5% and sales rose 0.3%, driving the inventory/sales ratio up to 1.38 from 1.37 in May.
Finally, import prices rose an as-expected 0.1% last month, but export prices jumped 0.4%, double what Wall Street projected.
In corporate news, retail earnings added to the heavy tone on the sector with Dick's Sporting Goods ( DKS ) and Advanced Auto Parts ( AAP ) reporting below-consensus earnings.
As a result shares of Dick's set a 6-year low, while Advanced Auto fell to its lowest level since October 2013.

Coach ( COH ) reported below-consensus revenue for Q2 before Tuesday's opening bell, and Dow component stock Home Depot ( HD ) shares were trading nearly 3% lower despite better-than-expected Q2 results.
European equities closed higher after Pyongyang blinked on Guam, and as soft U.K. inflation data drove sterling to a one-month low.
U.K. shares outperformed followed by modest gains in France's CAC-40.
Crude oil was down $0.32 to $47.28 per barrel.
Natural gas was down $0.01 to $2.98 per 1 million BTU.
Gold was down $11.70 to $1,278.70 an ounce, while silver was down $0.48 to $16.64 an ounce.
Copper was down $0.02 to $2.88 per pound.
Among energy ETFs, the United States Oil Fund was down 0.2% to $9.70 with the United States Natural Gas Fund was down 0.30% to $6.63.
Amongst precious-metal funds, the Market Vectors Gold Miners ETF was down 1.10% to 22.58 while SPDR Gold Shares were down 0.72% to $121.05.
The iShares Silver Trust was down 2.29% to $15.76.

Here's where the markets stand at mid-day:

NYSE Composite Index was down 12.61 points (-0.11%) to 11,843.45

Dow Jones Industrial Index was down 6.24 points (-0.03%) to 21,987.00

S&P 500 was down 2.51 points (-0.10%) to 2,463.36

Nasdaq Composite Index was down 9.39 points (-0.15%) to 6,330.84

FTSE 100 was up 29.96 points (+0.41%) to 7,383.85

DAX was up 11.92 points (+0.10%) to 12,177.04

CAC 40 was up 18.58 points (+0.36%) to 5,140.25

Hang Seng Index was down 75.27 points (-0.28%) to 27,174.96

Shanghai China Composite Index was up 13.90 points (+0.43%) to 3,251.26

NYSE Energy Sector Index was down 80.08 points (-0.80%) to 9,946.69

NYSE Financial Sector Index was down 1.34 points (-0.02%) to 7,589.36

NYSE Healthcare Sector Index was up 29.99 points (+0.22%) to 13,531.81
